reviewText: I really enjoyed this hour-long documentary on the making of D2's Rio and the interviews with both most of the band members and several of their friends and colleagues.  The best part was watching the breakdown of the tracks behind the mixing board and hearing each individual part.  You really got a good idea how the creative process came about, and how the members fed off each other creatively.  There is also some history on how the band got started due to John and Nick's virtually life-long friendship, and there is plenty here about shooting those still outstanding videos that made them a household name.  This documentary only goes to prove how wrong critics and certain other people were in labeling them as lightweight contenders who would never be remembered 5 years down the road.  Well, Rio is now 30 years old, and even a new generation of fans is being born as we speak.  It appears to me that D2 has that staying power after all, and for good reason.  They had, and still have, plenty of talent, and Rio is simply a magical album that deserves its place in rock history along with anything their contemporaries and their classic influences have laid down.  It's long past time to give these guys their due, and they all seem to have grown up a lot since the petty things that drove them apart when they were younger.  Too bad Andy was not present for any of it.  I would have loved to get some input from him, but he's off doing his Tina Louise-like disassociating bit again.  His loss, I guess.  Well, let this be your gain.  This DVD is worth your time, and it will make you appreciate Rio even more than you did before.
summary: Great Overview of D2's Best Known Album.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Rio is just about a perfect album. It's got fantastic hits we all know (Rio, Hungry Like the Wolf, Save a Prayer) a few awesome album cuts that could have easily been hits (Hold Back the Rain, My Own Way, Last Chance on the Stairway) and some arty, darker songs that showed just how talented these guys were (the Chauffeur, New Religion). It might be too good-there was no way they'd ever top it.The extras are fantastic--the original U.S. releases are still my favorites, as I grew up with them, and prefer them to the UK versions. The b-sides are all great.The only downside is that it's the only reissue that didn't come with videos and live concert footage, but there's no shortage of that elsewhere. A wonderful album and package. Too bad it didn't come out 15 years ago when we all really wanted it and would have bought it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This album defined the sound of an era (early 1980's).  MIDI was new and nothing was standardized yet with regards to studio gear, software, etc... This DVD gives the viewer a glimpse into those early days of 'hybrid productions' between new electronic MIDI (and NON-MIDI) instruments and traditional Rock and Disco bands... With the technology and software that we have today running our DAW's, you can just imagine pulling your hair out back then attempting to sync, record and edit tracks that only take us a few seconds and a few mouse clicks to accomplish, took them days (sometimes weeks) back then...

reviewText: A Fabulous trip through the making of a Fabulous album. Interesting info about how they came up with the songs and how each was made and mixed.  Great Commentary by the Band and others involved.

reviewText: This is a must for any Durannie! They explain how the songs of the "Rio" album were created (album and videos), not only that, they also explain how the band was formed (with particular anecdotes). All the members of the band are interviewed (except for Andy, you know). This is a recent interview that shows picture and video footage never seen before from the early days. Besides that there are several songs from "Rio" that are performed on studio. The DVD is not faulty, I've played this disc on my two players and it played very well on both. I hope there will be more documentaries for more Duran Duran's albums.

reviewText: Now reviewing after 3 years.Yeah I'm kinda slow!LOL!Love switching my DD DVD collections,Live from London,Rio,and first album.Like the interviews and looking back at the videos.Why the ......!?.Because for me,it a great album,but I like the first album more.From what I can see,Simon brought most of the lyrics from first 2 albums when he joined the band,so the material had to be split up.I love Hungry Like the Wolf,New Religion,and even My Own Way,the video that is.Rio itself doesn't do it for me.For me.I could listen to Planet Earth and Night Boat all day long.I'm weird like that!After that,Girls On Film and Late Bar.

reviewText: The very important thing that this DVD is missing is participation from Andy. They could have at least have talked to him and gotten his take on things. I was really interested in hearing what he thought about things, the musical inspirations he had while putting "Rio" together and everything else. I miss him.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Classic Albums:  ALWAYS GREAT.  Needless to say, a Classic Albums episode about one of my favorite albums from one of my favorite bands, a no-brainer.  Four of the original five Durans are present to break down the making of several of the key tracks, isolating each particular sound from the mix and explaining how and why it sounds the way it does.  The show also serves as a nice time capsule about a moment in the group's career:  about to become a huge worldwide sensation, but still in posession of their youthful exuberance.  A real delight, even if you're not a hardcore fan.Note:  original guitarist Andy Taylor is not interviewed, as this show was produced shortly following his (second) split from the band.
Title: N/A
